results.abstract: What's Doing In article on Perth, Australia; table; map; photos (L)
results.snippet: Enriched by discoveries of gold and diamonds and tucked between expanses of treeless plains and an even vaster Indian ocean, Perth is a bright nugget of civilization amid much emptiness. Farther from Sydney than from Jakarta, Perth is one of the...
results.lead_paragraph: Enriched by discoveries of gold and diamonds and tucked between expanses of treeless plains and an even vaster Indian ocean, Perth is a bright nugget of civilization amid much emptiness. Farther from Sydney than from Jakarta, Perth is one of the world's most isolated major cities, and while it's smaller than Sydney and Melbourne, it's growing faster than either. It is the capital of the gargantuan state of Western Australia, three times the size of Texas. Most of the state's two million inhabitants live in and around the city. In 1962 Perth achieved global renown as a beacon for the astronaut John Glenn: to help him get his bearings while in orbit, citizens switched on every light. He called it the City of Lights. Perth is also a city of white boats, black swans, magnificent beaches along the Sunset Coast of the Indian Ocean and 8,000 species of wildflower -- from orchids and everlastings to kangaroo paws. And now that spring has come to the Southern Hemisphere, they are in bloom. Kings Park, a leisurely walk from Perth's center, is one place to see them, but because of the Los Angeles-like climate, everybody's garden blazes with flowers all year. Spring temperatures are balmy -- in the 70's and 80's -- but Perth rivals Chicago when it comes to wind.

results.abstract: Russian astronauts successfully remove damaged solar panel from Mir space station in six-hour space walk (S)

headline.main: World News Briefs; Russians Fix Mir Panel In a 6-Hour Space Walk

results.snippet: In a six-hour space walk, two Russian astronauts today successfully dismantled a failing solar panel on the space station Mir and made more repairs to the battered space station despite last minute delays.    The space walk went smoothly,  with the...
results.lead_paragraph: In a six-hour space walk, two Russian astronauts today successfully dismantled a failing solar panel on the space station Mir and made more repairs to the battered space station despite last minute delays. The space walk went smoothly, with the Mir commander, Anatoly Solovyov, and a crew member, Pavel Vinogradov, removing the solar panel. A new panel is to be installed Thursday on a second space walk.

results.abstract: Jane Brody Personal Health column, second of two on adolescent girls' health, focuses on what parents can do to ease crisis in self-confidence that girls may experience when they enter puberty; advises parents, who are crucial in shaping children's sense of themselves, to encourage a daughter to test her mettle against challenging tasks, and to praise her for efforts, not just successes (M)

headline.main: Personal Health; Parents Can Bolster Girls' Fragile Self-Esteem

results.snippet: ALTHOUGH opportunities for girls and young women to develop to their fullest potential as human beings have never been greater than they are today in the United States, several studies in recent years have documented that far more girls than boys...
results.lead_paragraph: ALTHOUGH opportunities for girls and young women to develop to their fullest potential as human beings have never been greater than they are today in the United States, several studies in recent years have documented that far more girls than boys founder on route. Girls are more likely than boys to experience a crisis in self-confidence as they enter puberty. Too many girls turn their attention from what they can do to what they look like and seek to bolster their egos and counter their uncertainties by smoking, drinking, using drugs and getting pregnant.

results.abstract: New Orleans Parish School Board, following policy that prohibits school names honoring former slave owners, has voted unanimously to change name of George Washington Elementary to Dr Charles Richard Drew Elementary; new name pays tribute to black surgeon who is known for developing methods to preserve blood plasma and for protesting US Army's practice of segregating donated blood by race; renaming of 74-year-old school, 22d name change in New Orleans in five years, is latest milestone in concerted effort by blacks across South to assert their vision of biracial history that has traditionally been defined only by whites; never before has school shed name of figure as central to national identity as Washington; photo (M)

headline.main: Blacks Strip Slaveholders' Names Off Schools

results.snippet: By the reckoning of John Riley, the historian at Mount Vernon, there are about 450 schools in the United States named for George Washington.    Now there is one fewer. Following a policy that prohibits school names honoring ''former slave owners or...
results.lead_paragraph: By the reckoning of John Riley, the historian at Mount Vernon, there are about 450 schools in the United States named for George Washington. Now there is one fewer. Following a policy that prohibits school names honoring ''former slave owners or others who did not respect equal opportunity for all,'' the Orleans Parish School Board voted unanimously on Oct. 27 to change the name of George Washington Elementary to Dr. Charles Richard Drew Elementary.

results.abstract: Catharine Carver, who won trans-Atlantic esteem as editor of galaxy of mid-20th century authors, dies at 76 (S)

headline.main: Catharine Carver, 76, an Editor Of a Luminous List of Writers

results.snippet: Catharine Carver, who won trans-Atlantic esteem as the editor of a galaxy of mid-20th century authors, including Hannah Arendt, John Berryman, Saul Bellow and Flannery O'Connor, died on Tuesday at the Chelsea and Westminster Hospital in London. Ms....
results.lead_paragraph: Catharine Carver, who won trans-Atlantic esteem as the editor of a galaxy of mid-20th century authors, including Hannah Arendt, John Berryman, Saul Bellow and Flannery O'Connor, died on Tuesday at the Chelsea and Westminster Hospital in London. Ms. Carver, an American who lived in London, was 76. Friends said she died after a series of strokes.

results.abstract: Article on controlling pests that can infest apple trees; photos (L)

headline.main: Controlling Pests Without Growing Poison Apples

results.snippet: With more forethought, Adam might not have bitten the apple and I might not have planted apple trees. I did not realize that apple trees had so many pest problems, especially in the Northeast. But Adam did bite the apple, and I did plant apples -- 25...
results.lead_paragraph: With more forethought, Adam might not have bitten the apple and I might not have planted apple trees. I did not realize that apple trees had so many pest problems, especially in the Northeast. But Adam did bite the apple, and I did plant apples -- 25 dwarf trees -- and we both had to face the consequences. I could have resorted to the usually recommended seasonlong drenching of my trees with pesticides to kill every insect and fungus. But I researched potential problems to see how little, if any, pesticide I could use and still harvest an acceptable crop of high-quality apples. Though pest damage can result in little or no edible fruit, actually only a few pests cause most of the damage.

results.abstract: Astronauts aboard space shuttle Columbia successfully retrieve errant Spartan astronomy satellite (M)

headline.main: Astronauts Make a Good Grab And Bring Satellite Back In

results.snippet: Two astronauts aboard the space shuttle Columbia used their hands to grab the errant Spartan astronomy satellite yesterday after the two craft came together 170 miles above Earth.    The shuttle commander, Kevin R. Kregel, delicately maneuvered his...
results.lead_paragraph: Two astronauts aboard the space shuttle Columbia used their hands to grab the errant Spartan astronomy satellite yesterday after the two craft came together 170 miles above Earth. The shuttle commander, Kevin R. Kregel, delicately maneuvered his 100-ton craft until it closed in from below on the 3,000-pound satellite, which was inadvertently sent into a slow spin when it was released by the shuttle's crew last week. Waiting in the Columbia's open cargo bay for the satellite to drift into their reach, Winston E. Scott and Takao Doi grabbed it with their gloved hands and pulled it aboard at 9:09 P.M.

results.abstract: Astronauts on space shuttle Columbia may be able to put satellite they rescued in daring space walk back into orbit right away (S)

headline.main: Satellite Could Be Sent Back Out Right Away

results.snippet: The astronauts on the space shuttle Columbia may be able to put the satellite they rescued in a daring space walk back into orbit right away, NASA officials said today.    That would enable the Spartan satellite to observe the sun's charged outer...
results.lead_paragraph: The astronauts on the space shuttle Columbia may be able to put the satellite they rescued in a daring space walk back into orbit right away, NASA officials said today. That would enable the Spartan satellite to observe the sun's charged outer atmosphere, as planned before the satellite was accidentally sent into a slow spin last week, but a shortage of battery power could truncate the mission.

results.abstract: Time magazine has been flooded with letters, faxes and e-mails from Turks who want Mustafa Kemal Ataturk, founder of modern Turkey, to be included in Time's special issue celebrating century's outstanding figures in five broad categories; most public appeals have not mentioned that Time editors plan to make choices themselves, and that idea of asking for nominations is promotional lure; Turks are so determined that Ataturk be included that they are casting votes for him in every category, including century's greatest entertainer; photo (M)

headline.main: Istanbul Journal; Turks, Ever Zealous, Storm a Magazine's Stunt

results.snippet: It is a truism here that Mustafa Kemal Ataturk, the founder of modern Turkey, was the greatest statesman of the 20th century, if not of all time.  But now millions of Turks are claiming that he was also a more brilliant scientist than Einstein and a...
results.lead_paragraph: It is a truism here that Mustafa Kemal Ataturk, the founder of modern Turkey, was the greatest statesman of the 20th century, if not of all time. But now millions of Turks are claiming that he was also a more brilliant scientist than Einstein and a better singer than Elvis. Ataturk, who died in 1938, is worshiped here as a near-deity by the great majority of Turks who see him as a symbol of this country's Western and secular principles. The latest frenzy of adulation, however, has pushed him to a new level.

results.abstract: School systems nationwide are investing in high-priced computers and software in conviction, fostered by White House, that computers are best thing for American schoolchildren; but much of what passes for education on computers is akin to glorified video games offered in vague but firm belief that access to endless information, regardless of quality, must be good; even some computer experts are skeptical, saying computers can become distraction from other learning; computer debate is part of larger one on nature and purpose of education; photo (M)

headline.main: The Nation; High-Tech Teaching Is Losing Its Gloss

results.snippet: TWO Pilgrims, Priscilla Mullens and Elder Brewster, went on line this month to answer questions from schoolchildren around the country about the first Thanksgiving in 1621.    The actors who played them, guests of the Scholastic Network, were from...
results.lead_paragraph: TWO Pilgrims, Priscilla Mullens and Elder Brewster, went on line this month to answer questions from schoolchildren around the country about the first Thanksgiving in 1621. The actors who played them, guests of the Scholastic Network, were from Plimouth Plantation, the museum in Massachusetts, and they offered an austere picture of life in the colony, where surgeons bled their patients and John Alden's bride-to-be treasured the wooden shoes her father made her.

results.abstract: Charles Strum article on popular Star Trek television series notes that Star Trek: Voyager is latest version of original 1966 series; photos (M)
results.snippet: THIRTY-ONE years ago Neil Armstrong was just another NASA astronaut, and a Moon walk -- the Armstrong original as well as the Michael Jackson knockoff -- had not yet been imagined. But Kirk, Spock and Bones were becoming real heroes of the 23d...
results.lead_paragraph: THIRTY-ONE years ago Neil Armstrong was just another NASA astronaut, and a Moon walk -- the Armstrong original as well as the Michael Jackson knockoff -- had not yet been imagined. But Kirk, Spock and Bones were becoming real heroes of the 23d century, and this one, too. They are heroes still, as are Picard and Sisko and now Janeway, commanders of a Federation starship maintaining course through a fourth decade, a fourth television incarnation, eight movies (a ninth is on the way) and deeper into popular culture, if that is possible. Their exploration of the galaxy, now a 24th-century phenomenon, is 350 episodes along, with no end in sight. It's as if science fiction had finally come up with a perpetual-entertainment machine.
